items.synopsis: Voters in NSW, Tasmania and SA have voted against the Voice to Parliament, dashing proponents' hopes of securing a double majority. Follow all the results with our live blog.

title.children: Voice to Parliament referendum defeated as three states vote No

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's 6pm in the Northern Territory where polls have now closed. Australians have voted against establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the constitution.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Polls have closed in the Northern Territory

featuredLink.title: Australians reject Indigenous recognition via Voice to Parliament

children.content: It's 6pm in the
Northern Territory
where polls have now closed.
Australians have
voted against
establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the constitution.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians have voted against establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the constitution. The ABC projects that a majority of voters in South Australia have voted No to the proposed constitutional change, along with a majority of voters in New South Wales and Tasmania. It means the proposal has not secured support from enough states to pass. The request for a Voice was made by Indigenous Australians who took part in the Uluru Dialogues and issued the Statement from the Heart six years ago. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese committed his government to implementing the Uluru statement “in full” in his election victory speech in May last year. He argued it would deliver practical benefits, contribute to meeting Closing the Gap targets, and give long overdue recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the constitution. But Australian voters have today rejected that pathway.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ABC projection: The Voice referendum has been defeated

featuredLink.title: Australians reject Indigenous recognition via Voice to Parliament

children.content: Australians have
voted against
establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the constitution.
The ABC projects that a majority of voters in South Australia have voted No to the proposed constitutional change, along with a majority of voters in New South Wales and Tasmania.
It means the proposal
has not secured support from enough states to pass
The request for a Voice was made by Indigenous Australians who took part in the Uluru Dialogues and issued the Statement from the Heart six years ago.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese committed his government to implementing the Uluru statement “in full” in his election victory speech in May last year.
He argued it would deliver practical benefits, contribute to meeting Closing the Gap targets, and give long overdue recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the constitution.
But Australian voters have today rejected that pathway.

items.synopsis: A flight for Australians to evacuate Israel has been cancelled, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has announced. Follow live.

title.children: Repatriation flights cancelled for Australians as Israel issues six-hour window for evacuations from Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Smartraveller has just confirmed that Australian repatriation flights that were scheduled to leave Tel Aviv today will not depart. Here's the statement: The situation is highly challenging and rapidly changing. Unfortunately, we have been advised our scheduled flights will not depart Israel today. A further flight will not depart as scheduled tomorrow. The Australian Government is working to ensure Australians who want to leave can do so as soon as possible. We will communicate to registered Australians about next available flights. Australians in Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories should register via https://crisis.dfat.gov.au/crisisportal/s/ or by calling the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian repatriation flights from Israel cancelled

children.content: Smartraveller has just confirmed that Australian repatriation flights that were scheduled to leave Tel Aviv today will not depart. Here's the statement:

The situation is highly challenging and rapidly changing. Unfortunately, we have been advised our scheduled flights will not depart Israel today. A further flight will not depart as scheduled tomorrow.
The Australian Government is working to ensure Australians who want to leave can do so as soon as possible. We will communicate to registered Australians about next available flights.
Australians in Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories should register via
https://crisis.dfat.gov.au/crisisportal/s/
or by calling the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from Australia).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia will provide an initial $10 million in humanitarian assistance for civilians affected by the conflict in Gaza. That will be split between $3 million through the International Committee of the Red Cross to fund "urgent needs like restoring essential services and providing medical support to victims of the conflict" and $7 million through United Nations agencies providing critical aid. The UN support will include emergency water supplies, nutrition, sanitation and hygiene services and child protection. The Gaza Strip has been cut off from food, water and fuel supplies coming through Israel, with electricity also cut and several health facilities damaged in air strikes. "We have seen devastating loss of innocent life since the heinous attacks on Israel by brutal terrorist group Hamas," Foreign Minister Penny Wong said. "Far from representing the Palestinian people, Hamas undermines Palestinian needs and aspirations. "We continue to call for the unconditional release of all hostages. We stand with Israel and reiterate its right to defend itself. "President Biden has called on Israel to operate by the rules of war in its response to Hamas attacks — we join him and others in that call. "We call for safe and unimpeded humanitarian access to civilians affected by the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza. "We call for the establishment of a corridor to enable humanitarian needs to be met. And we support the work of the United States, Egypt and others towards this goal. "Adherence to international humanitarian law must be prioritised — including the protection of civilians, wherever they live."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia announces $10 million in aid for civilians in Gaza

children.content: Australia will provide an initial $10 million in humanitarian assistance for civilians affected by the conflict in Gaza.
That will be split between $3 million through the International Committee of the Red Cross to fund "urgent needs
like restoring essential services and providing medical support to victims of the conflict" and $7 million through United Nations agencies providing critical aid.
The UN support will include emergency water supplies, nutrition, sanitation and hygiene services and child protection.
The Gaza Strip has been cut off from food, water and fuel supplies coming through Israel, with electricity also cut and several health facilities damaged in air strikes.

props.alt: A girl sits next to containers as Palestinians gather to fill water from public taps amid the conflict with Israel in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, October 11, 2023.

children.content: People in Gaza have been filling water containers to get by.
(Reuters: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa)
"We have seen devastating loss of innocent life since the heinous attacks on Israel by brutal terrorist group Hamas," Foreign Minister Penny Wong said.
"Far from representing the Palestinian people, Hamas undermines Palestinian needs and aspirations.
"We continue to call for the unconditional release of all hostages. We stand with Israel and reiterate its right to defend itself.
"President Biden has called on Israel to operate by the rules of war in its response to Hamas attacks — we join him and others in that call.
"We call for safe and unimpeded humanitarian access to civilians affected by the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
"We call for the establishment of a corridor to enable humanitarian needs to be met. And we support the work of the United States, Egypt and others towards this goal.
"Adherence to international humanitarian law must be prioritised — including the protection of civilians, wherever they live."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli Army arabic language spokesman Avichay Adraee has posted on X, formerly Twitter, that residents of Gaza City will be allowed to leave on two roads between 10am and 4pm local time. It's currently just before 9am in Gaza. The post on X, which includes a map, translated from Arabic into English reads: An important statement to the residents of Gaza City  In recent days, we have appealed to you to leave Gaza City to the south of Wadi Gaza in order to preserve your safety. I would like to inform you that the IDF will allow movement on the indicated streets without any harm between the hours of 10:00-16:00. For your safety, take advantage of the short time to move south — from Beit Hanoun to Khan Yunis. If you care about yourself and your loved ones, go south as instructed. Rest assured that Hamas leaders have taken care of themselves and are taking cover from strikes in the region. Residents of Al-Shati, Rimal, and west of Zeitoun will also be allowed to move on Daldul and Al-Seena Streets towards Salah Al-Deen and Al-Bahr Streets. Note: The translation of this tweet has been updated to correct several town names.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli Army will allow safe movement out of Gaza City for six hours

children.content: The Israeli Army arabic language spokesman Avichay Adraee has posted on X, formerly Twitter, that residents of Gaza City will be allowed to leave on two roads between 10am and 4pm local time.
It's currently just before 9am in Gaza.
The post on X, which includes a map, translated from Arabic into English reads:

An important statement to the residents of Gaza City  In recent days, we have appealed to you to leave Gaza City to the south of Wadi Gaza in order to preserve your safety. I would like to inform you that the IDF will allow movement on the indicated streets without any harm between the hours of 10:00-16:00. For your safety, take advantage of the short time to move south — from Beit Hanoun to Khan Yunis. If you care about yourself and your loved ones, go south as instructed. Rest assured that Hamas leaders have taken care of themselves and are taking cover from strikes in the region. Residents of Al-Shati, Rimal, and west of Zeitoun will also be allowed to move on Daldul and Al-Seena Streets towards Salah Al-Deen and Al-Bahr Streets.
Note: The translation of this tweet has been updated to correct several town names.

title.children: In their distorted Cinderella legend, the Beckhams get the last laugh

items.synopsis: When Lauren Bouyer tries to conjure an image in her mind's eye, nothing happens. Researchers say her condition, aphantasia, is more prevalent than previously thought.

title.children: Loren can't 'see' things in her imagination. It's more common than you might think
